sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a reaction involving aqueous solutions
message_1:
Calculate the standard enthalpy change for the reaction: 
2 NaOH(aq) + H2SO4(aq) → Na2SO4(aq) + 2 H2O(l)
Given the following data:
ΔHf°(NaOH) = -469.14 kJ/mol
ΔHf°(H2SO4) = -814.00 kJ/mol
ΔHf°(Na2SO4) = -1388.40 kJ/mol
ΔHf°(H2O(l)) = -285.83 kJ/mol
message_2:
To calculate the standard enthalpy change for the reaction, we can use the following formula:

ΔH°(reaction) = Σ ΔHf°(products) - Σ ΔHf°(reactants)

For the reactants:
2 moles of NaOH: 2 × (-469.14 kJ/mol) = -938.28 kJ
1 mole of H2SO4: 1 × (-814.00 kJ/mol) = -814.00 kJ

For the products:
1 mole of Na2SO4: 1 × (-1388.40 kJ/mol) = -1388.40 kJ
2 moles of H2O(l): 2 × (-285.83 kJ/mol) = -571.66 kJ

Now, we can plug these values into the formula:

ΔH°(reaction) = (-1388.40 kJ + (-571.66 kJ)) - (-938.28 kJ + (-814.00 kJ))
ΔH°(reaction) = (-1960.06 kJ) - (-1752.28 kJ)
ΔH°(reaction) = 207.78 kJ

The standard enthalpy change for the reaction is 207.78 kJ.
